name: sodium benzoate
notes: Common in acidic beverages and condiments.
effect: May trigger allergic reactions, asthma, or hyperactivity in sensitive individuals.

name: benzoic acid
notes: Parent compound of benzoates; used in acidic foods.
effect: Generally recognized as safe, but excessive intake may irritate the stomach.

name: potassium sorbate
notes: Often used in cheeses, baked goods, juices.
effect: Considered safe, but may cause mild skin or respiratory irritation in sensitive people.

name: sorbic acid
notes: Acid form; similar use to sorbates.
effect: Low-toxicity preservative, but excessive intake may upset digestion.

name: calcium propionate
notes: Common bread preservative to inhibit mold.
effect: May trigger migraines or hyperactivity in some sensitive individuals.

name: sodium nitrite
effect: Can form carcinogenic nitrosamines when heated; linked to increased cancer risk if consumed frequently.

name: sodium nitrate
notes: Converted to nitrite in meat processing.
effect: Similar risks as nitrites; may contribute to cancer risk in processed meats.

name: potassium nitrate
effect: Generally safe in small amounts, but long-term intake linked to stomach irritation and possible cancer risk.

name: sulfur dioxide
notes: Common in dried fruits and wine.
effect: May trigger asthma attacks and allergic reactions; best avoided by sensitive individuals.

name: sodium metabisulfite
effect: Can cause allergic reactions, headaches, or asthma flare-ups in sensitive people.

name: potassium metabisulfite
effect: May trigger asthma or allergic reactions in sensitive individuals; best avoided by sulfite-sensitive people.

name: BHA
effect: Possible endocrine disruptor; linked to cancer in animal studies. Best minimized.

name: BHT
notes: Used to stabilize oils and cereals.
effect: Suspected to disrupt hormones; limited intake recommended.

name: TBHQ
notes: Used in frying oils and snacks.
effect: May cause nausea or hyperactivity; high doses linked to immune and neurological effects.

name: natamycin
notes: Surface treatment for cheeses and sausages.
effect: Generally safe; minimal absorption in the body, but overuse may contribute to antifungal resistance.

name: sucrose
notes: Common sugar from cane or beet.
effect: Excess intake contributes to obesity, diabetes, and tooth decay.

name: glucose
notes: Often used in bakery and confections.
effect: Spikes blood sugar rapidly; best limited for metabolic health.

name: fructose
notes: Fruit sugar; also used in syrups.
effect: Processed fructose (not whole fruit) stresses the liver and may promote insulin resistance.

name: high fructose corn syrup
notes: Corn-derived syrup with higher fructose content.
effect: Linked to obesity, diabetes, and metabolic issues with overconsumption.

name: lactose
effect: Can cause digestive discomfort in lactose-intolerant individuals.

name: maltose
effect: Moderate effect on blood sugar; excessive intake may contribute to weight gain.

name: invert sugar
effect: Raises blood sugar quickly; frequent use may contribute to metabolic issues.

name: stevia extract
effect: Generally safe; may help reduce blood sugar spikes compared to regular sugar.

name: monk fruit extract
effect: Considered safe and natural; good alternative for managing blood sugar.

name: sucralose
effect: May disrupt gut bacteria and increase cravings for sweet foods.

name: aspartame
effect: Unsafe for people with PKU; may cause headaches or mood changes in sensitive individuals.

name: acesulfame potassium
effect: Generally recognized as safe, but animal studies suggest possible effects on insulin response.

name: saccharin
effect: Linked to bladder cancer in early studies; now considered safe at low doses, but may cause bitter aftertaste.

name: erythritol
effect: Generally well tolerated, but high intake may cause digestive upset in sensitive people.

name: xylitol
effect: Helps prevent cavities; may cause bloating or diarrhea in excess.

name: sorbitol
effect: Can cause gas, bloating, and diarrhea in sensitive individuals when consumed in large amounts.

name: maltitol
effect: May cause digestive upset and laxative effects if consumed in excess.

name: isomalt
effect: Generally safe, but large amounts may lead to bloating or diarrhea.

name: caramel color
effect: Certain classes may contain 4-MEI, a potential carcinogen; safer in moderation.

name: annatto
effect: Generally safe; may cause rare allergic reactions.

name: beta-carotene
effect: Supports eye and skin health; excessive supplements may increase cancer risk in smokers.

name: beet juice color
effect: Safe and natural; provides antioxidants.

name: paprika extract
effect: Safe and natural; may contain beneficial carotenoids.

name: turmeric extract
effect: Anti-inflammatory properties; beneficial in moderate dietary amounts.

name: spirulina extract
effect: Safe and nutrient-rich; contains antioxidants and proteins.

name: titanium dioxide
notes: Used to whiten; subject to regional regulations.
effect: Controversial; may cause inflammation at high exposure levels. Restricted in the EU.

name: FD&C Red 40
effect: Linked to hyperactivity and behavioral issues in children; best avoided by sensitive individuals.

name: FD&C Yellow 5
effect: May trigger allergies or asthma; linked to hyperactivity in children.

name: FD&C Yellow 6
effect: Associated with allergic reactions and behavioral issues; restricted in some countries.

name: FD&C Blue 1
effect: Generally considered safe, but may cause allergic reactions in sensitive individuals.

name: FD&C Blue 2
effect: Animal studies suggest potential cancer risk; precautionary avoidance is recommended.

name: FD&C Green 3
effect: Possible allergic reactions; limited safety data compared to other dyes.

name: soy lecithin
effect: Generally safe; may cause issues for those with soy allergies.

name: sunflower lecithin
effect: Safe and well tolerated; often preferred over soy lecithin.

name: mono- and diglycerides
notes: From fats and oils; may be animal- or plant-derived.
effect: Can contain trans fat residues; moderate consumption advised.

name: DATEM
aliases: diacetyl tartaric acid esters of mono- and diglycerides
effect: Generally recognized as safe, but may cause digestive upset in sensitive individuals.

name: polysorbate 80
notes: Used in ice creams and sauces.
effect: May disrupt gut barrier function in animal studies; best limited for gut health.

name: polysorbate 60
notes: Used in whipped toppings, baked goods.
effect: Considered safe in small amounts, but excessive intake may affect digestion.

name: carrageenan
notes: From red seaweed; used in dairy alternatives.
effect: Linked to gut inflammation in some studies; may worsen digestive issues for sensitive individuals.

name: gellan gum
effect: Generally well tolerated, though excess intake may cause bloating.

name: guar gum
notes: From guar beans; often in gluten-free baking.
effect: Can help with blood sugar control; high amounts may cause gas or bloating.

name: xanthan gum
effect: Safe for most, but large doses may cause digestive discomfort.

name: locust bean gum
effect: Generally safe; beneficial fiber, but excess may cause gas.

name: agar
effect: Safe and natural; may support digestion as a mild laxative.

name: pectin
effect: Supports gut health as soluble fiber; generally beneficial.

name: cellulose gum
effect: Non-digestible; excessive intake may cause bloating or loose stools.

name: methylcellulose
effect: Used as a laxative in supplements; large amounts in food may cause digestive upset.

name: microcrystalline cellulose
effect: Non-digestible fiber; safe for most, though high intake may cause bloating.

name: propylene glycol alginate
effect: Generally considered safe, but high consumption may affect digestion.

name: modified food starch
effect: Safe for most people; can raise blood sugar quickly if heavily refined.

name: citric acid
effect: Generally safe; may irritate mouth ulcers in sensitive individuals.

name: malic acid
effect: Safe in normal amounts; excessive intake may cause tooth enamel erosion.

name: lactic acid
effect: Generally safe; supports gut health in fermented foods.

name: tartaric acid
notes: Found in grapes and wine products.
effect: Safe in small amounts; high doses may cause stomach irritation.

name: acetic acid
effect: Supports blood sugar control; excessive intake may damage tooth enamel.

name: phosphoric acid
effect: Excessive intake linked to lower bone density and kidney stress.

name: ascorbic acid
effect: Supports immune function and reduces oxidative stress; generally beneficial.

name: monosodium glutamate
effect: Safe for most, though some report headaches or sensitivity (‘Chinese restaurant syndrome’).

name: disodium inosinate
effect: Enhances savory flavor; often paired with MSG. Should be avoided by people with gout due to purine content.

name: disodium guanylate
effect: Generally safe; may worsen symptoms in gout patients.

name: yeast extract
effect: Natural source of umami; may trigger reactions in people sensitive to MSG-like compounds.

name: hydrolyzed vegetable protein
notes: Protein hydrolysates used for savory flavor.
effect: Can contain free glutamates similar to MSG; may cause sensitivity in some individuals.

name: sodium bicarbonate
notes: Reacts with acids to release CO2.
effect: Safe in moderate amounts; excessive intake may cause alkalosis or stomach upset.

name: monocalcium phosphate
effect: Generally recognized as safe; excess phosphorus may affect bone balance if consumed in large amounts.

name: sodium aluminum phosphate
effect: Safe in small amounts; high aluminum intake may raise concerns about neurological effects.

name: ammonium bicarbonate
effect: Considered safe; breaks down into ammonia and CO2 during baking, leaving no residue.

name: silicon dioxide
effect: Generally safe; excessive intake from supplements may stress kidneys.

name: calcium silicate
notes: Absorbs moisture in salts and powders.
effect: Safe at food levels; high supplemental intake may affect calcium balance.

name: magnesium stearate
effect: Safe in small amounts; excess may cause digestive upset.

name: dimethylpolysiloxane
effect: Generally safe; extremely small amounts are used in food.

name: glycerin
effect: Safe for most; excessive intake may cause headaches, nausea, or diarrhea.

name: propylene glycol
effect: Safe at food levels; very high intake may cause kidney or liver stress.

name: L-cysteine
effect: Generally safe, but may be sourced from animal products (not vegetarian-friendly).

name: enzymes
notes: Used in bakery; typically not active in finished foods.
effect: Safe; helps improve bread texture. Usually deactivated during baking.

name: wheat flour
notes: Base flour in many baked goods.
effect: Staple food; problematic for people with gluten sensitivity or celiac disease.

name: rice flour
effect: Safe and gluten-free; often used as a wheat alternative.

name: tapioca starch
effect: Gluten-free thickener; generally safe but high intake offers little nutrition.

name: potato starch
effect: Safe; provides resistant starch that may benefit gut health.

name: corn starch
effect: Safe; high use in processed foods adds calories with little nutrition.

name: inulin
notes: Prebiotic fiber from chicory; may affect GI comfort.
effect: Supports gut health as a prebiotic; excess may cause gas or bloating.

name: oligofructose
effect: Feeds healthy gut bacteria; too much may cause digestive discomfort.

name: gelatin
effect: Provides collagen; unsuitable for vegetarians and vegans.

name: pea protein
effect: Nutritious, allergen-friendly protein source; may cause gas in sensitive individuals.

name: whey protein concentrate
effect: High-quality protein; not suitable for lactose-intolerant individuals.

name: caseinate
effect: Useful protein additive; may trigger dairy allergies or intolerances.

name: canola oil
effect: Generally safe; refining reduces nutrients, but moderate use is acceptable.

name: soybean oil
effect: High in omega-6 fatty acids; excessive intake may promote inflammation.

name: palm oil
effect: Stable for cooking, but high intake may raise cholesterol. Environmental concerns with production.

name: palm kernel oil
notes: Harder fat fraction from palm kernel.
effect: High in saturated fats; may raise LDL cholesterol if consumed excessively.

name: coconut oil
effect: Provides medium-chain triglycerides (MCTs); beneficial in moderation but raises cholesterol at high intake.

name: olive oil
notes: Extra virgin used for flavor; refined for frying.
effect: Rich in antioxidants and monounsaturated fats; supports heart health.

name: shortening
notes: May contain partially hydrogenated oils depending on region/regulations.
effect: Often high in trans fats; strongly linked to heart disease. Best avoided.

name: natural flavors
notes: Complex mixtures derived from natural sources.
effect: Considered safe, though vague labeling makes it hard to know exact source. May cause reactions in sensitive people.

name: artificial flavors
effect: Regulated as safe, but offer no nutritional benefit; may contribute to chemical sensitivity.

name: smoke flavor
effect: Generally safe; contains natural compounds that may irritate sensitive individuals.

name: salt
effect: Essential mineral; excess intake linked to high blood pressure and cardiovascular risk.

name: spices
notes: Generic label term for spice blends.
effect: Safe and natural; specific health effects depend on the individual spices used.

name: herbs
effect: Safe and beneficial; contain antioxidants and anti-inflammatory compounds.

name: coffee extract
effect: Provides caffeine boost; may cause jitters or sleep issues if overconsumed.

name: vanilla extract
effect: Safe and natural; provides antioxidants and pleasant flavor.

name: vanillin
effect: Considered safe; lacks beneficial compounds found in real vanilla.
